newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Hong Kong stocks drift lower in morning trade.
newsitem.headline: Hong Kong stocks drift lower in morning trade.

text.p: Hong Kong stocks drifted lower in Tuesday morning trad, shedding a quick 30-gain at the market consolidated recent gains, brokers said.

"After having gained so much ground, we expect some consolidation," said Peter Lui in institutional sales at NAVA SC Securities. "But any consolidation is likely to be short-lived, only two to three days."
The Hang Seng Index was down 19 points at 12,491. Turnover was HK$1.28 billion after the first 30 minutes of trade.
The blue chip index rose 73.25 points to hit a new record close of 12,510.25 on Friday.
Technical analysts said the market is looking very overbought and a healthy consolidation would be a good sign.

"Short-term, we need to see a consolidation, even as much as 500 points would be good," said Alan Shum, research manager at New Century Securities. "Medium-term, the index is still on course to hit 13,000."
Traders remained cautiously optimistic that market activity would remain robust enough to support further gains.
"Turnover will be the key," said Ronald Lam. "We are not likely to reach 13,000 without turnover of HK$7 billion to HHK$8 billion."
NAVA's Lui said that the market is still in the process of a rerating, which would bring the index to a valuation of 17 times to 18 times prospective earnings.
"We are still seeing foreign investor interest in the Bank (HSBC) and other blue chips," said Lam.

All blue chip sectors were down in early trade with the exception of the utilities. The commercial and industrial sector came in for the heaviest profit-taking with CITIC Pacific down HK$0.70 at HK$37.00 and Swire Pacific off HK$0.75 at HK$71.00.
Hong Kong Telecom inched up HK$0.05 to HK$13.75, while China Light lost HK$0.20 to HK$37.00.
HSBC opened up HK$156.00, an all-time high, then eased to trade HK$0.50 up at HK$155.50. The share was the most active in early trade.
Subsidiary Hang Seng Bank led the losers with a net change of HK$0.75 to HK$92.25.
Hopewell also remained high on the most active list, gaining HK$0.10 to HK$5.40 on trade of HK$103.02 million.
